thread.section_title: Australian Business & World Finance News - Yahoo!7 Finance
thread.title: $A falls after weak Chinese data

title: $A falls after weak Chinese data
text:
Tue, Sep 1, 2015, 6:18 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A falls after weak Chinese data AAP – 8 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar has been dragged lower by weak Chinese economic data and signs of no change in the Reserve Bank's cash rate any time soon. 
At 1700 AEST on Tuesday, the local unit was trading at 71.08 US cents, down from 71.42 cents on Monday. 
The currency fell after the Reserve Bank kept the cash rate unchanged at its September board meeting, and gave no indication it will cut again any time soon, despite recent falls on global share markets. 
FxPro chief economist Simon Smith said the weakest Chinese manufacturing activity in three years, indicating the sector had contracted, was also a blow to market confidence. 
"Although the latest Chinese PMI data for the manufacturing sector was in line, the fact that it was below 50 has weighed on sentiment," he said. 
"The Shanghai composite index is languishing in negative territory once again and dragging most other indices in Asia with it." 
Mr Smith said a recovery in oil prices had helped the Australian dollar reduce some of its losses. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 85.68 Japanese yen, down from Monday's close of 86.54 yen, and at 63.01 euro cents, down from 63.62 euro cents. 
The bond market was stronger as equity markets fell. 
"People are terrified of these horrible equities markets across the world and technical positions look horrible and one wonders who is going to be buying into the dip," Westpac senior market strategist Damien McColough said. 
Bonds also got a boost from international trade data that indicated Wednesday's GDP figures might be weaker than first thought. 
"That balance of payments data was sufficient to get the market to accelerate its questioning on whether the GDP data could be a small negative tomorrow," he said. 
At 1630 AEST on Tuesday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.330 (implying a yield of 2.670 per cent), up from 97.305 (2.695 per cent) on Monday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.230 (1.770 per cent), steady with the previous local close. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Myer stakes fashion rep on Topshop AAP
